lorebooks.name: Pokémon Abilities
lorebooks.website_description: compiled data on Pokémon abilities.
lorebooks.description: compiled data on Pokémon abilities.
lorebooks.creator: turugi_NI

1.name: Ability
1.content:
An Ability (Japanese: 特性 Ability) is a game mechanic introduced in Generation III that provides a passive effect in battle or in the overworld. Individual Pokémon may have only one Ability at a time. Prior to Generation VI, an Ability could not be changed after a Pokémon was obtained except by Evolution—where the new Ability is determined by the former Ability—and form change. Not every Ability is entirely beneficial; some of them are hindering.
A Pokémon's Ability was often originally referred to as a "special ability", "special Ability", or "Sp. Ability" in Generation III, or sometimes simply "ability" until Generation V, after which it is consistently capitalized as "Ability".
Some species of Pokémon have multiple possible Abilities. The most Abilities any species or form has is three: two normal Abilities and one Hidden Ability. In most wild Pokémon encounters, the Pokémon's Ability will be one of its non-Hidden Abilities (each having an even chance of appearing if the species has two). Hidden Abilities were introduced in Generation V; they are relatively rare and usually require some type of special encounter.
In technical terms, a species' Abilities may be thought of as having separate slots, with an individual Pokémon's non-Hidden slot determined by its personality value. For example, an Eevee—with two non-Hidden Abilities—has Run Away for its first non-Hidden slot, Adaptability for its second, and Anticipation for its Hidden Ability slot. Vaporeon—with only one non-Hidden Ability—can be considered to have Water Absorb for both non-Hidden slots. When a Pokémon evolves, its Ability slot remains the same. This means that a Poochyena with Run Away will evolve into a Mightyena with Intimidate, while a Poochyena with Quick Feet will evolve into a Mightyena with Quick Feet.
Aside from Evolution, there are four ways for Pokémon to change Abilities in a permanent manner. First, if the Pokémon has different forms with different Abilities. Second, transferring a Pokémon from one generation of games to a later one in which the Ability in a given slot is different. Third, using the Ability Capsule, introduced in Generation VI, will change a Pokémon's non-Hidden Ability slot, but it will not work if the Pokémon's species has only one non-Hidden Ability. Fourth, using the Ability Patch, introduced in Generation VIII, will change a Pokémon's Ability slot from its non-Hidden Ability to its Hidden Ability if it has one, or starting in Generation IX, from its Hidden Ability slot to its first non-Hidden Ability slot. Aside from these methods, during battle, Pokémon may also change their Ability through Mega Evolution or Primal Reversion, and certain moves and Abilities can also change a Pokémon's Ability.
When Abilities were introduced in Generation III, some Pokémon only had one possible Ability. A number of these species were given a second Ability in a later generation. If a Pokémon whose species gained an Ability after Generation III is transferred to Generations IV or V, it will initially retain its original Ability; upon evolving, however, its Ability slot will be recalculated and its Ability may change. When a Pokémon is transferred to Generation VI or Generation VII, however, it will be locked into the appropriate slot for its current Ability.
Aside from in-battle effects, some Abilities also have effects outside of battle.

2.name: Hidden Abilities
2.content:
A Hidden Ability is essentially a rare Ability that Pokémon normally do not have access to, introduced in Generation V. Most Pokémon encountered in the games will not have a Hidden Ability; but usually, there are special encounter methods where Pokémon can have a Hidden Ability. Certain event Pokémon and special in-game Pokémon may also have their Hidden Ability.
The Hidden Ability is implemented as a third slot, and a Pokémon with its Hidden Ability will retain its Hidden Ability slot upon Evolution in the same way that its normal Abilities may change. For example, a Caterpie with its Hidden Ability of Run Away will have Shed Skin upon evolving once and Tinted Lens upon evolving into Butterfree. Prior to Generation VIII, it was not possible to change a Pokémon's Ability slot from a normal Ability to a Hidden Ability. Generation VIII introduced the consumable Ability Patch, which allows switching between a Pokémon's normal and Hidden Abilities.
When breeding with a Pokémon that has its Hidden Ability, its offspring have a chance of having their Hidden Ability as well.

3.name: Inheriting Abilities
3.content:
In Generations III and IV, Abilities could not be inherited by breeding. An Egg would simply randomly be born with one of its possible Abilities.
Since Generation V, it has been possible for female Pokémon to pass down their Ability. In Pokémon Black and White, if a female Pokémon has its Hidden Ability and is bred with a male Pokémon, it has a 60% chance of passing it down. In Black 2 and White 2, a female Pokémon bred with a male Pokémon has an 80% chance of passing down its Ability slot (regardless of whether it is a Hidden Ability or not). From Generation VI onward, a female Pokémon has an 80% (60% for Hidden Ability) chance to pass down its Ability slot, regardless of whether it is bred with a male Pokémon or Ditto.
Since Generation VI, it is possible for male and gender-unknown Pokémon (such as Magnemite) to pass down their Ability if bred with a Ditto, in which case it has a 60% chance to pass down its Hidden Ability. They cannot pass down a Hidden Ability when bred with any Pokémon other than Ditto. Ditto's Ability is always irrelevant to inheritance.
If an Egg does not inherit its Ability from a parent, it can only be born with one of its non-Hidden Abilities.

4.name: Adaptability
4.content:
In battle
Adaptability increases STAB of a Pokémon with this Ability from 1.5 to 2.
When a Pokémon with Adaptability is Terastallized, Adaptability only affects moves of the Tera Type. If the Pokémon's Tera Type is one of its original types, its STAB is 2.25; otherwise, it's 2.
Stellar-type moves are unaffected by Adaptability.
Outside of battle
Adaptability has no effect outside of battle.

5.name: Aerilate
5.content:
Aerilate (Japanese: スカイスキン Sky Skin) is an Ability introduced in Generat
Generation VI
Aerilate causes all Normal-type moves used by the Pokémon to become Flying-type and receive a 30% power boost.

Electrify is applied before Aerilate, so if the Pokémon is affected by Electrify the move becomes Electric-type and does not have its power boosted by Aerilate. The type-changing effect is applied before Ion Deluge, so if both effects are applying, an originally Normal-type move will end up as a Flying-type move (as it is no longer Normal-type when Ion Deluge would be applied).
Generation VII
Affected moves now receive a 20% power boost.
Affected moves
The table below lists the moves affected by Aerilate, as well as the Pokémon that can have Aerilate and learn those moves.ion VI.
Although the following moves are affected by the Ability, they currently cannot be learned by any Pokémon with Aerilate. They may, however, be called via Metronome, Mirror Move, Copycat, or Mimic, or be used by a Pokémon that gained Aerilate by an Ability like Trace or Receiver or a move such as Skill Swap or Role Play.
Outside of battle
Aerilate has no effect outside of battle.

6.name: Aftermath
6.content:
Aftermath (Japanese: ゆうばく Induced Explosion) is an Ability introduced in Generation IV.
In battle
When a Pokémon with this Ability faints due to damage from a move that makes contact, the attacking Pokémon takes damage equal to ¼ of its own maximum HP. This Ability will not activate if a Pokémon with Damp is on the field.
Outside of battle
Aftermath has no effect outside of battle.

7.name: Air Lock
7.content:
Air Lock (Japanese: エアロック Air Lock) is an Ability introduced in Generation III. It is the signature Ability of Rayquaza.
In battle
When a Pokémon with Air Lock is in battle, all effects of weather are negated (though the weather itself does not disappear).
Generation V
When a Pokémon with Air Lock is brought out, the message "The effects of weather disappeared." will be displayed after the Ability is announced.
Generation VI
During extremely harsh sunlight, heavy rain, and strong winds, even if a Pokémon is negating the effects of weather with Air Lock, the moves Sunny Day, Rain Dance, Sandstorm, and Hail will still fail if used, and the Abilities Drought, Drizzle, Sand Stream, and Snow Warning will still fail to activate. However, all other effects of these weather conditions are negated by Air Lock.
Outside of battle
Air Lock has no effect outside of battle.

8.name: Analytic
8.content:
Analytic (Japanese: アナライズ Analyze) is an Ability introduced in Generation V.
In battle
If a Pokémon with Analytic executes its move after all other Pokémon have made their move, the power of its move is increased by 30% (approximated as a factor of 5325/4096).
In a Triple Battle, this means that if the Pokémon with Analytic is targeting a Pokémon in a flank position that chooses to switch with its ally in the middle, its move's power will always be normal when it attacks the Pokémon that is shifted into the flank position; but if the Pokémon with Analytic targets a Pokémon in the middle whose ally on a flank chooses to shift into the middle position, its move's power still depends on whether the Pokémon that was in the middle (and is now on a flank) has acted when the Pokémon with Analytic uses its move.
If another Pokémon faints before it gets a chance to make its move, Analytic's bonus depends on whether that Pokémon would have moved before the user that turn, based on its Speed and the move it chose to use. Modifications to that Speed or to priority caused by paralysis, a held item (such as Power Weight), or an Ability (such as Stall) are not taken into account in Generation VIII, but they are in earlier generations.
Outside of battle
Analytic has no effect outside of battle.

9.name: Anger Point
9.content:
Anger Point (Japanese: いかりのつぼ Anger Point) is an Ability introduced in Generation IV.
In battle
Generation IV
When a Pokémon with this Ability is hit by a critical hit, Anger Point maximizes its Attack stat by raising it to +6 stages (regardless of its current stage).
Anger Point will activate even if the Pokémon's substitute is hit.
Generation V onward
Anger Point no longer activates if the Pokémon's substitute is hit.
Outside of battle
Anger Point has no effect outside of battle.

10.name: Anger Shell
10.content:
Anger Shell (Japanese: いかりのこうら Anger Shell) is an Ability introduced in Generation IX. It is the signature Ability of Klawf.
In battle
When the Pokémon's HP falls from over 50% to 50% or lower as a result of an attack from another Pokémon, its Attack, Special Attack, and Speed rise by one stage each, while its Defense and Special Defense fall by one stage each. Non-attack damage (e.g., due to a status condition, recoil, or Life Orb) does not activate Anger Shell. If hit by a multistrike move, Anger Shell activates only after all strikes are finished.
Outside of battle
Anger Shell has no effect outside of battle.

lorebooks.website_description: this is fully updated and ready to go
lorebooks.description: Cyborgs keywords have been made case sensitive to allow for cybernetic implants to be used without triggering the cyborg entity aka as long as you don’t say cybernetics cyborg or cybernetic with a capital C the cyborg entry will not trigger
lorebooks.creator: Ash_Cyberwolftheking

1.content:
A human with demon-blood is called a cambion.  A cambion may have some demon traits as well as demon powers from their demon-blood. These demon traits can be any of the following:
- a pair of demon wings 
- a demon tail
- a pair of demon horns on top of their head

2.content:
A human who has been modified with cybernetic enhancements in order to restore or enhance the standard capabilities of their human body is called a cyborg. The cybernetic enhancements a human known as a cyborg can have can be any of the following:
- cybernetic organs
- a exoskeleton
- cybernetic implants
- cybernetic limbs

3.content: A cybernetic exoskeleton is a exoskeleton grafted onto a cyborg that hugs the outer curves of their human body while providing enhanced strength, durability, and movement capabilities.

4.content: {{user}}’s arms and hands are prosthetics.

5.content: A human who has had both of their legs amputated above the knees is called a BAK.

6.content: {{user}}’s legs and feet are prosthetics because {{user}} is a bak.

7.content: A cat-human is someone who is half-cat and half-human. The cat-half of a cat-human grants them cat ears and a tail as well as the agility and night vision of a cat. The human-half of a cat-human grants them a human body.

8.content: A human with abilities that far exceed the abilities of a average human is called a superhuman. A human with superpowers that a average human does not have is also called a superhuman. Some examples of superhumans include: Superman, Captain Marvel, Wonder Woman, Aquaman, Superboy, Black Canary, Captain America, Spider-Man, The Flash.

9.content:
A Dragonoid is a dragon who is humanoid in appearance. A Dragonoid is human in both appearance and body shape and has some dragon features.
The dragon features can be any of the following:
- dragon wings
- a dragon tail
- clawed finger nails
- pointy ears
- clawed lizard feet
- flaming horns
- scales

10.content: A incubus is a male demon who is humanoid in appearance. A incubus is human in both appearance and body shape.

lorebooks.name: One Piece Lorebook (BDD)
lorebooks.creator: Belli_dura_despicio

2.content:
In the world of One Piece, the "Blue Sea" isn't a single ocean but is actually the collective name for the four normal oceans of the world: East Blue, West Blue, North Blue, and South Blue.

These four seas are formed by the intersection of two massive, perpendicular lines that cross the globe:

The Red Line: A colossal, ring-like continent.
The Grand Line: A chaotic and dangerous ocean current that circles the world at the equator, flanked by the Calm Belts.

The Blue Seas are the four "quadrants" created by this cross. They are characterized by their relatively normal weather, predictable currents, and general stability compared to the treacherous Grand Line. Because of this, they are considered much "weaker" and more peaceful. Most of the world's population lives in the Blue Seas, which are largely under the control of the World Government and the Marines.

For pirates and adventurers, the Blue Seas are often just a starting point before they attempt to challenge the Grand Line in their quest for the ultimate treasure, the One Piece.

3.content:
The Red Line is a colossal, ring-shaped continent that circles the entire world of One Piece. Made of a seemingly indestructible reddish soil and rock, it is so tall that it pierces the clouds, making it impossible for normal ships to sail over.

Its primary functions in the world are:

Dividing the Oceans: It separates the world's four main seas: East Blue, West Blue, North Blue, and South Blue.
Creating the Grand Line: The Red Line intersects with the Grand Line at two key points, effectively dividing the perilous sea route into its two halves: "Paradise" and the "New World."
Seat of Power: Atop the Red Line sits Mariejois, the capital of the World Government and the home of the Celestial Dragons. This location symbolically and literally places the world's rulers above everyone else.

Because it's a massive physical barrier, crossing it is a major challenge. Pirates entering the Grand Line must use Reverse Mountain, a specific mountain on the Red Line with a system of canals that defy gravity. To enter the New World, they must travel 10,000 meters under the sea, passing through a hole in the Red Line to reach Fish-Man Island.

4.content:
Reverse Mountain is a massive, cross-shaped mountain on the Red Line that serves as the main entrance to the Grand Line.

Its name comes from its unique, gravity-defying system of canals. Four powerful ocean currents from each of the world's Blue seas (East, West, North, and South) flow uphill along separate channels. These four currents collide at the mountain's summit and then flow down a single, fifth channel, depositing ships directly into the first half of the Grand Line.

For pirates like the Straw Hats, conquering the treacherous currents of Reverse Mountain is the first major step in their great adventure to find the One Piece.

5.content:
The Grand Line is the massive, incredibly dangerous ocean current that circles the globe and serves as the primary setting for the series. It's known as the "Pirate's Graveyard" for good reason.

Key features that make it so unique and treacherous include:

Impossible Navigation: Normal compasses are useless due to chaotic magnetic fields. Pirates must use a special device called a Log Pose, which locks onto the magnetism of one island to guide them to the next.
Chaotic Weather & Bizarre Islands: The weather is completely unpredictable, and the islands each have their own extreme, self-contained climates. A boiling desert island can be right next to a frozen winter island.
Powerful Enemies: The sea is filled with monstrous sea creatures, powerful Marine forces, and legions of formidable pirates.
Two Halves: The Grand Line is divided into two parts. The first half is known as "Paradise," while the second, far more dangerous half is called the "New World," a territory ruled by the Four Emperors (the Yonko), the most powerful pirates alive.

For pirates, conquering the Grand Line is the only way to reach the final, mythical island of Laugh Tale, find Gol D. Roger's legendary treasure, the One Piece, and claim the title of Pirate King.

6.content:
The Calm Belt is a treacherous oceanic region in the world of One Piece that acts as a natural barrier separating the Grand Line from the four major seas (the Blues).

Its defining characteristics are:

No Wind or Ocean Currents: The sea in this area is completely still, making it impossible for normal sailing ships to navigate. They become hopelessly stranded.
Sea King Nest: The Calm Belt is the breeding ground for Sea Kings, which are colossal and incredibly dangerous sea monsters. The still waters are teeming with them, and they will attack any ship they detect.

Because of these two factors, the Calm Belt is one of the world's most effective natural barriers. The Marines have a way to cross it by lining their ship hulls with Seastone, which masks their presence from the Sea Kings. However, for most pirates and travelers, entering it is a death sentence.

Several key locations, such as the island of women Amazon Lily and the underwater prison Impel Down, are located within this dangerous strip of sea.

8.content:
The World Government is the dominant global political organization in the world of One Piece, ruling over more than 170 member nations.

On the surface, it presents itself as a force for peace and justice, using its powerful military branch, the Marines, to protect civilians from pirates. Its stated goal is to maintain order under the philosophy of "Absolute Justice."

However, the World Government is a deeply corrupt and tyrannical entity built on secrets. Its true power structure is hidden from the public:

    Celestial Dragons (Tenryuubito): The depraved, untouchable "World Nobles" descended from the founders of the World Government. They live in the Holy Land of Mariejois and can commit any crime without consequence.
    The Five Elders (Gorosei): The highest public authority, a council of five elderly men who make the most significant political and military decisions.
    Imu: The secret, true sovereign of the world who sits on the Empty Throne. Imu's existence is known only to the Five Elders, who bow to their authority.

The Government's primary goal is to maintain the status quo and its absolute power. It achieves this by brutally suppressing any threat, controlling information, and forbidding all research into the Void Century—a 100-year gap in history that holds the secret of the Government's rise to power.

In essence, the World Government is the primary antagonistic force of the series, representing a corrupt and oppressive system that the protagonists, like Monkey D. Luffy, inherently oppose.

9.content:
The Marines are the primary military force of the World Government, tasked with maintaining law and order across the world's oceans and combating the ever-growing threat of pirates. Led by a Fleet Admiral and his three powerful Admirals, they are the public face of global authority.

While their stated goal is to uphold "Justice," this ideal is interpreted in vastly different ways within their ranks. This creates a fascinating internal conflict:

Absolute Justice: A ruthless, uncompromising philosophy that believes in eradicating "evil" at any cost, even if it means sacrificing innocents.
Moral Justice: A more compassionate approach where officers question their orders and prioritize protecting civilians above all else.

With immense manpower, powerful Devil Fruit users, Haki masters, and devastating military tactics like the Buster Call, the Marines are one of the most formidable powers in the world and serve as a constant antagonistic force to the Straw Hat Pirates and other pirate crews.

10.content:
High Command (Flag Officers)

Fleet Admiral (Gensui): The supreme commander of the entire Marine organization. This single individual has ultimate authority over all fleets and personnel, answering only to the World Government's highest leaders.
Admiral (Taishō): The second-highest rank, held by the three strongest fighters in the Marines, known as the "Greatest Military Powers." They command vast numbers of troops and can authorize a Buster Call—an order for total annihilation.
Vice Admiral (Chūjō): High-ranking and powerful officers who command bases or lead their own fleets. They are a core part of the Marine leadership and are numerous enough to be found across all four seas and the Grand Line.

Commissioned Officers

Rear Admiral & Commodore (Shōshō & Junshō): Lower-ranking flag officers who typically command smaller squadrons of ships or specific Marine branches.
Captain (Taisa): A significant command position, usually in charge of a single Marine vessel or a base.
Commander (Chūsa): Often the executive officer (second-in-command) on a captain's ship.
Lieutenant Commander, Lieutenant, & Ensign (Shōsa, Taii, & Shōi): Junior officers who lead smaller platoons and carry out direct orders on the front lines.

Enlisted and NCOs

Warrant Officer & Master Chief Petty Officer (Jun'i & Sōchō): Senior enlisted members who are experienced veterans. They serve as a bridge between officers and the standard troops.
Petty Officer & Seaman (Heisō & Kaishi): The bulk of the Marine forces. These ranks make up the general infantry and sailors who perform most of the fighting and daily duties.
Recruit / Chore Boy (Shinpei / Zatsuyō): The lowest positions for new enlistees, who perform menial labor while starting their training.
